Hello Ken-

Thanks for the thought-provoking response. I'd like to think about your
answers a bit before responding.

However, if you have a second, I would be interested to hear your thoughts
on what I originally intended to be my main question, which is this:

>> The paper seems to further suggest that the reason many of these problems
>> are deceptive is because (a) it is easier to learn a fixed-heuristic, and
>> then (b) there is a fitness valley between that fixed-heuristic and the
>> adaptive strategy.
>> 
>> I agree with (a) (in most cases), but why assume (b)?

Much of analysis in the paper hinges on the fact that there is actually a
fitness valley between a fixed-heuristic and learning. But do we know that
is the case for your experiment? Is it usually the case? Why?

For me, questions on this front are really intriguing and, before your
paper, I had not spent much time thinking about them. An understanding of
them might really help our field better evolve adaptive agents.


Cheers,
Jeff
